data.title: The Invisible Culling: Delhi’s Quiet Holocaust

children.text: The vans arrive in the grey light of dawn. They don’t come for criminals; they come for the "unwanted."

For years, these residents lived among us. They shared our streets, watched our children grow, and survived on the scraps of our mercy. But a new order has been issued. The city must be "cleansed." The command is simple: round them up, take them away, and clear the sightlines of the modern metropolis.

They are herded into cramped, metal cages. There is no explanation, only the rough hands of workers and the cold clatter of locks. They are driven to the outskirts, to "camps" hidden behind high walls, far away from the eyes of the public who used to feed them.

Inside these walls, the story of "protection" turns into a nightmare. They are packed together in filth. Food is a memory. Disease spreads like wildfire through the ranks. The workers no longer see them as living beings; they are just tasks to be managed, numbers to be cleared. The public is told this is for the greater good—for "safety" and "cleanliness." But behind the gates, a mass disappearance is happening.
This sounds like a chapter from the Holocaust, a dark history of how societies "sanitize" themselves by removing the vulnerable. But this isn't Nazi Germany.
This is Delhi, right now.

Under aggressive new government drives to "beautify" the city, the stray dogs of Delhi are being treated like victims of a systematic cleansing. As highlighted by reports from the Rohini shelter home, these dogs are being snatched from their neighborhoods and thrown into overcrowded, makeshift prisons.
According to investigations by The Indian Express and local activists, the reality inside is horrific:
Starvation and Neglect: Dogs are being left without food or water, leading to skeletal remains and infighting.
The "Black Box" Policy: Once a dog is taken, the community is often blocked from seeing it or ensuring its return, effectively making them "disappeared" residents.
Mass Death: The lack of medical care in these shelters has turned "relocation" into a death sentence.
A Call to Conscience

We cannot afford to look away while our city's silent companions are marched into the shadows. This is not just about animals; it is about the soul of a society that decides "beautification" is worth the price of state-sponsored cruelty.

History teaches us that the road to atrocity begins with the normalization of suffering. If we allow these "shelters" to remain unaccountable death traps, we are complicit in a mass cleansing that goes against every grain of humanity.
The time to act is now. Do not let the silence of the camps become the silence of our city. Stand against this injustice before the streets are emptied and our humanity is lost.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) has rapidly transformed many fields, including software development. Tools like code generators, debugging assistants, and automated testing systems have raised an important question: Can AI replace coders? While AI has become a powerful helper in programming, it is unlikely to completely replace human coders in the foreseeable future.

AI can already perform many coding-related tasks efficiently. It can generate boilerplate code, suggest improvements, detect bugs, and even write simple programs based on prompts. This has significantly increased productivity and reduced repetitive work for developers. For beginners, AI makes learning to code easier by providing explanations and instant feedback. In industries, AI helps speed up development cycles and reduce costs.

However, coding is not just about writing lines of code. It involves problem-solving, logical thinking, creativity, and understanding real-world requirements. Humans decide what needs to be built and why, while AI only works based on the instructions and data it is given. AI lacks true understanding, emotions, ethics, and contextual awareness. It cannot independently design complex systems, make judgment calls, or fully understand user needs the way humans can.

Moreover, software development often requires teamwork, communication with clients, adapting to changing requirements, and making decisions in uncertain situations. These human skills are difficult for AI to replicate. AI-generated code can also contain errors, security risks, or inefficiencies that require human review and responsibility.

Instead of replacing coders, AI is more likely to change the role of coders. Programmers will work alongside AI, using it as a tool to enhance their abilities. Coders will focus more on system design, logic, creativity, and decision-making, while AI handles repetitive and time-consuming tasks.

In conclusion, AI will not replace coders but will empower them. The future belongs to developers who can effectively use AI as a tool. Rather than fearing AI, coders should learn to collaborate with it, as human intelligence and creativity remain essential in building meaningful and reliable software.
